body: Found a problem (see #218) but this is now fixed.  Everything looks good now.

Hey Guys,

Mike & I have finished up a release candidate 1 from the current codebase and set of changes marked for alpha-1 release.

It's on the sonatype nexus OSS staging repository located here:
https://oss.sonatype.org/content/repositories/iofluo-1000/

There's a branch for tracking the release candidate here: fluo-1.0.0-alpha-1-rc1 

The current SHA1 for the release commit is: 69ec547a308d6b764b89bbd2b1714a9697777261

https://oss.sonatype.org/content/repositories/iofluo-1000/io/fluo/fluo-distribution/1.0.0-alpha-1/fluo-distribution-1.0.0-alpha-1-bin.tar.gz
Successfully ran on 20-node cluster.  Ran trie stress test and loaded 2000 integers.  Stress test completed with expected result.
Was this run on the release candidate? Could we post a comment on there with the results?
Yes it was run on the release candidate.  I'll add a comment.

I ran the trie stess test on a 20-node cluster and loaded 2000 integers.  The count at the root node was 2000 as expected so the test ran successfully.  This is very good news given that this stress test was failing when run on the cluster a few months ago.  See #226
After some discussions with mike walch- we may try putting this in the new website repo.
This ticket also changes master back to a snapshot version (which was overlooked while Mike Walch & I were doing the alpha-1 release candidate today.)

Also- after a +1, this should be manually merged back to the alpha-1 branch. Thinking about this- it's going to get a bit weird doing pull requests when we have multiple version branches going on. We should probably start using discretion when auto-merging them through the UI and maybe +1 instead by default. Mike & I were discussing today the possibility of using the labels on the tickets to mark any other version lines in which commits against a ticket should apply- it seems like this is a reasonable workaround for Github not allowing multiple milestones to be marked on a ticket.

I thought about this some more.  I think each issue should have multiple pull requests if a code change needs to be applied to multiple versions.  Each pull request should be set to the correct milestone.  For historical records, the pull requests will show that the issue was resolved in a particular version.  When issues are created, the description could say if multiple versions need to be fixed.  I think this will allow us to avoid having to label issues with versions which confuses label & milestones.

So how do the tickets get filed? We need 3 tickets for each bug fix or task
that needs to be applied to multiple versions?

See my response in #230.  I think we should create a pull request for each version.
For reviews, a pull request for one version can be submitted first.  After +1 or request is merged, other pull requests could be created.  Any review for additional pull requests would be minimal.

This is getting a little complicated and seems like it may break down in
scenarios where pull requests have gotten out of date. I'm kind of in the
camp of getting the initial code reviewed and merging forward but I'm
trying to think if that breaks down as well.
On Sep 30, 2014 8:20 AM, "Mike Walch" notifications@github.com wrote:

> For reviews, a pull request for one version can be submitted first. After
> +1 or request is merged, other pull requests could be created. Any review
> for additional pull requests would be minimal.
> 
> —

> https://github.com/fluo-io/fluo/issues/230#issuecomment-57304766.
A pull request is still needed for 1.0.0-alpha branch

I this should be backed out and the initial commit applied against alpha2.
We need merge commits against the branches to keep future merges happy.
On Sep 30, 2014 8:29 AM, "Mike Walch" notifications@github.com wrote:

> Merged #228 https://github.com/fluo-io/fluo/pull/228.
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/fluo-io/fluo/pull/228#event-172045046.

I think we are saying the same thing.  You can create a change for alpha, get it reviewed, and then merge forward to create change for beta.  However, beta should still be a pull request even if it only need to be quickly reviewed.  I think we should avoid just pushing commits to master & major version branches without pull requests.
Sorry.. I misread your comment in the issue and didn't see that you wanted a +1 instead.  Do you want me to revert it? Or do you want to handle it?

> For reviews, a pull request for one version can be submitted first. After +1 or request is merged, other pull requests could be created. Any review for additional pull requests would be minimal.

I like this.   I have seen subtle bugs introduced on conflict resolutions gone wrong in Accumulo.   So in the commit messages, lets make sure we preserve the messages automatically generated about conflicts.

These pull request may merge multiple pull request from the lower branch.  But I think thats ok, its mainly reviewing conflict resolution, which should be quick.  If there are no conflicts it should be really quick.

Yeah I mean I don't disagree with having code reviewed. It's just very
cumbersome doing a separate branch and pull request for every merge that
needs to be made. And it seems like it's going to get much more cumbersome
when, for instance, multiple people have pull requests going on and there's
conflicts and rebases needed to be made before the pull request can be
merged.

We may also want to consider a workflow where master is our latest stable software.   All active development would occur on a release branch (1.0 branch, 1.1 branch, etc).  When a user clones the git repo, master is something thats ready to be built and used.   

I think we got this wrong on Accumulo.  We treated master like trunk in svn.

I believe this is how Linus Torvalds recommends doing it as well.

On Tue, Sep 30, 2014 at 10:33 AM, Keith Turner notifications@github.com
wrote:

> We may also want to consider a workflow where master is our latest stable
> software. All active development would occur on a release branch (1.0
> branch, 1.1 branch, etc). When a user clones the git repo, master is

>

> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub

No biggie, I just don't want to have to merge backwards but maybe this case will be an exception while we get used to our strategy.

>   We may also want to consider a workflow where master is our latest stable software. All active development would occur on a release branch (1.0 branch, 1.1 branch, etc). When a user clones the git repo, master is something thats ready to be built and used. 

Interesting idea but if TravisCI runs an automated build on every pull request to master then master should rarely be unstable.

>  It's just very cumbersome doing a separate branch and pull request for every merge that needs to be made

That may be.  I think we need to try to create a process that minimizes the amount of friction, and be willing to change a that process if we think of a better one.

> Interesting idea but if TravisCI runs an automated build on every pull request to master then master should rarely be unstable. 

I am thinking of stable as being more than it builds successfully.  I am thinking stable is what we would recommend users run in production.  For example Zookeeper did not declare 3.4.X stable and recommend users run it until 3.4.5.  I have no idea how they made that decision, but for a while after releasing 3.4.0 they continued to recommend running 3.3.6 in production.   However we decide what the latest stable release is (and this will change over time), I think it would be nice if master was equivalent to that.

So do we add that in after we have a stable version that we recommend to
use in production or do we use alpha-1 after it gets released?

than later, when we notice we're spending more time creating branches and
pull requests then we are fixing the bugs that apply to multiple versions.
Perhaps this is okay everyone and maybe the time spent on this is helping
the time spent debugging bad merges.

I checked the signature of the tarball last night and it looked good.

> I'm fine with giving it try, it just seems like it could be sooner rather than later, when we notice we're spending more time creating branches and pull requests then we are fixing the bugs that apply to multiple versions.

If we do end up in that state,  I think we will all grumble and want to come up with something better.   

> Perhaps this is okay everyone and maybe the time spent on this is helping the time spent debugging bad merges.

Right, time spent debugging issues that occur in production is an important consideration when trying to reason about the amount of time we spend on the process of trying to improve software quality.

> So do we add that in after we have a stable version that we recommend to use in production or do we use alpha-1 after it gets released?

Good question.  Maybe we should not have a master at all now, because there is no version we would recommend user run?  But thats confusing.    People expect a master branch.   To minimize confusion, maybe we could make master == alpha 1 for now?

Something to consider

http://nvie.com/posts/a-successful-git-branching-model/
So I take it you were able to reproduce this?
I was able to run the phrasecount example against 1.0.0-alpha-1 w/ one small change related to an API change.  I pointed maven to the staging repo inorder to do this.

> I ran the trie stess test on a 20-node cluster and loaded 2000 integers. 

did you use the tar ball in the staging repo to do this?
I checked the sig on the tar ball and a few of the jars, those looked good.

I like the model described in the blog post and I think it works great for projects where users clone master & build to get the latest release.  However, it could be confusing to users to use that model and also publish your jars & binaries.  How do users decide if they should build the latest from master or use the latest published binary/jar?

>  How do users decide if they should build the latest from master or use the latest published binary/jar? 

I was thinking master would always mirror the latest released version we recommend for production.

> did you use the tar ball in the staging repo to do this?

I built it from the release candidate branch fluo-1.0.0-alpha-1-rc1

+1.  I checked the signature on the tarball and several jars.  Reran the stress test using tar ball from staging with 5000 integers (loaded by 10 mappers each loading 500 int).  Node size was 8 bits.  Test ran for about 10 minutes after loading was finished and count at root node was 5000 as expected.

Also- I was finding that interaction with zookeeper was taking quite awhile as I was writing code directly against zookeeper and finding single requests to zookeeper taking several seconds to complete.

Yes.  I was able to reproduce it.  It could be an issue in Zookeeper.   

I think it's important that we fix this.  I don't want Mac users to start skipping tests due to this delay.

Just did a test run for the release plugin commit that I did earlier today. One thing I didn't even think about is that, unless we wait for each series of pull requests to be approved and do them in sequence, we are going to see commits with messages like "Merge branch 'fluo-227-alpha'". Maybe this is okay, but I'm just used to seeing version branch names in the merge commits.

Also, I agree with Keith about master being a production-quality version. It's easier to explain to a user that they may not be seeing bleeding-edge code but rather production quality code than it is to explain to them why the master build may still include large bugs (even though it passes all the tests).
Because this pull request includes an initial merge from alpha to beta, it will include a few different commits.

Not 100% sure about the following.   Looking at how this ended up working, I think the merge commit may have been uneeded, since the pull request will merge.  It may be that if you have a local branch based on alpha that you can always submit a merge request to beta w/o a merge as part of the pull req, if it merges cleanly.  If it does not merge cleanly, then may still need merge the resolves conflicts as part of pull req.  

This is something to try in the future.

Keith, 

Good point. This situation was a little different because a pull request had gotten merged in yesterday in beta and the change needed to be made separate in alpha so it could be rolled forward (instead of rolling backwards). I also noticed that the version in beta had been set to "fluo-1.0.0-beta-1" instead of just 1.0.0-beta-1 and I wanted to get that fixed. It didn't appear there was ever a merge commit establishing the pom version change between alpha and beta. I think you are right- if the merge can be made cleanly then we should try to establish the merge only in github instead of doing the merge commit manually and then introducing another one through the pull request.
I'm requesting the commit to go into fluo-io:1.0.0-alpha

I should not have merged #233 since there was comment here.   

I am thinking we should submit a pull req to alpha, and only after that is successfully in, then submit a pull req for beta.  Not do them concurrently.  Its all good as long as #232  branch is not be rebased.  We are learning as we go.

> I'm requesting the commit to go into fluo-io:1.0.0-alpha

hehe, yeah I have it all figured out now.  I noticed the the commit in beta branch before realizing it was in this pull request.  I was confused by the concurrent pull reqs.

Correction

I should not have merged #233 because #232 had the same commit, with a pending comment/review
@mikewalch and @cjnolet is it ok to merge this?
Before this ticket is closed a release should be created at https://github.com/fluo-io/fluo/releases
Done. I was able to release the artifacts from nexus today via the web but I needed to wait to push the tag until I could get on my laptop.

Also- before considered done, I'd also like to get release notes out and notify the community. I'm working on the release notes and will notify the community via the Accumulo user list after we get the initial site up and the quick start is accepted and merged.

Here's my release notes: # Fluo Release Notes Fluo 1.0.0-alpha-1 is the first official release of Fluo. It contains 83 initial tickets marked for this first milestone. The roadmap for this release included a working initial implementation, completing an initial pass at the client API, and writing a stress test application. ## Significant features This alpha release contained a lot of initial features to help establish the basic implementation and client API. All of these features will be expected to become more robust over time.

MiniFluo

MiniFluo helps to get a quickly fire up a MiniAccumulo instance, initialize Fluo, and run an Oracle and some number workers that can be used for integration testing. This has largely allowed Fluo to be developed without the need for a full cluster.

Observer API

Notifications allow processing to be done on a worker as data is modified in one or more watched columns. The Observer API allows users to deploy their notification handling logic to the workers so that the code can be run server-side.

Garbage Collection

Without garbage collection, the columnns in a Fluo table would grow without bound as updates are applied over time. Because of this, it's important to clean up old fully-processed (and no longer being read) transaction data. The initial implementation of garbage collection kept N versions of snapshots but Fluo-8 added the ability for garbage collection to collect all snapshots that are no longer being read by transactions anywhere else in the cluster.\

MapReduce InputFormat

The FluoInputFormat allows a specific snapshot to be read into a mapreduce job. It was established in Fluo-7

FluoFileOutputFormat and FluoOutputFormat

The FluoFileOuputFormat enables the bulk ingest of a Fluo table using mapreduce by creating the Accumulo r-files in HDFS. The FluoOutputFormat pushes keys directly into the Accumulo tablet servers through the client API. Fluo-35 added this feature.

Fluo Workers and Oracle running in Yarn

Fluo can use Yarn to manage fault tolerance and guarantee multiple worker processes and some number of Oracle processes are kept running across the cluster. Apache Twill was used for the Yarn integration. Fluo-11 added an application that will deploy Fluo to a Yarn cluster.

Oracle failover

The Oracle provides monotonically increasing transaction timestamps. Having multiple Oracles deployed on a cluster with the ability to failover is important to maintain high availability of Fluo transactions. Fluo-15 and Fluo-3 provide this.

Fluo API

Fluo provides a fluent-builder API for creating transactions to read and mutate data of various different data types in the Fluo table. This API was finalized in Fluo-23 and Fluo-98 when it was moved into its own module.

Stress test

In order to determine that the Fluo works as expected, a Stress test was created that uses a tree to force collisions on transactions trying to mutate multiple columns at the same time. This was established in Fluo-24 Other important improvements and features: - [Fluo-186] - Add Exceptions to API - [Fluo-175] - Add newTransaction() method to FluoClient - [Fluo-147] - Create fluo-accumulo module for Accumulo iterators and formatter - [Fluo-131] - Make LoaderExector implement closeable - [Fluo-130] - Expose MiniFluo in public API - [Fluo-123] - Hide implementation of Bytes in the API - [Fluo-98] - Create a Range class for Fluo - [Fluo-89] - OracleApp should allow configurable number of instances - [Fluo-16] - Allow observer notification to be configured in AbstractObserver class - [Fluo-13] - Register clients that perform transactions in Zookeeper - [Fluo-1] - Create scripts for starting/stopping services ## Testing Tests were run using the Stress test module. 1. Stress test was run successfully in < > minutes on 20-node cluster generating 2000 integers 2. Stress test was run successfully in 10 minutes on a < >-node cluster against 5000 integers

Yes I'll do that

Mike, if you wouldn't mind doing that, it'd be great. I'll set up Jekyll tonight when I get home
So these changes will produce a src tar that contains the same contents as the RC  tag?
Looking at this change it seems like sealing is off by default and will be activated during the release process?
Would be nice to have something like the [rc-verify script](https://github.com/ctubbsii/rc-verify) created by @ctubbsii for Accumulo
That rc-verify script is pretty neat. Wondering if we could use it as is and maybe contribute back to it.

And yes- sealing is off by default. I did it that way because sealing is off by default in Accumulo. Seems like something we should only need to do when releases happen- as we are trying to better the compatibility between versions.

> So these changes will produce a src tar that contains the same contents as the RC tag?

Correct- though the git information is dropped so it doesn't matter when the src changes are created so long as they are done during the release.

> Seems like something we should only need to do when releases happen

I agree, I just wanted to make sure I understood the change.

Does sealing the jar use your gpg key?

> Does sealing the jar use your gpg key?

Nevermind, sealing has nothing do with signing a jar.  I just read about it.

Jar sealing just prevents packages in the sealed jar from appearing in other jars. It can't be turned on during ITs in Accumulo, because the test jars on the classpath when the ITs run will have some of the same packages (to test package-private code). You may not need that if you stick to running ITs against the public API, and leave the testing of internal implementation to unit tests (which run before the jars are built, so sealing doesn't matter for those).

In order to get this out the door quickly, we chose to do a simple reinitialize property in the config. We've had a discussion on a design that should make it in to beta that will allow more comprehensive and easy-to-use reinitialize on the command line. We discussed this on #198 in depth.
+1.  I think some of logs can be reduced.  There is also an issue with Twill trying but failing to publish logs using Kafka.  It would be nice if this could be disabled too.

The more I'm thinking about this- it may make sense to do something similar to Accumulo and just not unclude the Hadoop, Zookeeper, and Accumulo dependencies in the final tarball- but instead allow the classpath property in the fluo worker to pick these jars up in the installed system.
Hey Mike- where are you noticing this? In the tarball that' sbeen released or in the current pom (for beta-1)? I fixed this last week
I saw that it was missing in the alpha-1 tarball that was released.  However, I just built master and the README.md is not included.

I was on the fence about that- README.md is in a good format for the github readme but wasn't sure if we should do a different readme for the plaintext version that gets shipped. It honestly doesn't matter much to me. Just that the markdown can be a tad more cumbersome as a plaintext README file
Nevermind- I like the use of - and = for the headings and the use of numerical (indexed) links. That makes it much easier to parse as a plaintext readme. +1. I'll do this tonight.
Is this done?
This is going to be tricky given that we are running the workers in YARN.  I am not sure what the best design but it might involve loading jars into HDFS and having workers pull them down.

Being able to load from HDFS would definitely be useful as well. I'm wondering if maybe a different configurable location on each node would be useful too (something that can be configured better @ the system level and better decoupled from our actual tarball if necessary). Assuming that would still want to give users the option to deploy a worker in, say Mesos, this would also allow that to be possible.

Crawl Rate = % of repository updated per hour over a billion document repository. 

Here's the excerpt from the paper:

"To quantify the benefits of moving from MapReduce to Percolator, we created a synthetic benchmark that clusters newly crawled documents against a billion document repository to remove duplicates in much the same way Google’s indexing pipeline operates. Documents are clustered by three clustering keys. In a real system, the clustering keys would be properties of the document like redirect target or content hash, but in this experiment we selected them uniformly at random from a collection of 750M possible keys. The average cluster in our synthetic repository contains 3.3 documents, and 93% of the documents are in a non-singleton cluster. This distribution of keys exercises the clustering logic, but does not expose it to the few extremely large clusters we have seen in practice. These clusters only affect the latency tail and not the results we present here. In the Percolator clustering implementation, each crawled document is immediately written to the repository to be clustered by an observer. The observer maintains an index table for each clustering key and compares the document against each index to determine if it is a duplicate (an elaboration of Figure 2). MapReduce implements clustering of continually arriving documents by repeatedly running a sequence of three clustering MapReduces (one for each clustering key). The sequence of three MapReduces processes the entire repository and any crawled documents that accumulated while the previous three were running."
Accumulo master is at 14. Looks like 15 was released toward the end of September. I don't mind updating.
Updated parent pom apache version to 15

I think we should just let yarn handle it.  If you want different jars, then shutdown the yarn app, replace the jars, and then start yarn app again.  Let yarn handle distribution of jars across cluster.  Unlike Accumulo where you want to avoid restarting tservers, its ok to stop and start workers as needed.   So I don't think we need to take an approach that avoid starting and stopping workers.

> I think we should just let yarn handle it. If you want different jars, then shutdown the yarn app, replace the jars, and then start yarn app again. Let yarn handle distribution of jars across cluster.

I like this approach.  We just need to consider the situation where workers are in the middle of processing notifications.  Our current **shutdown** of workers is more like a **kill**.  Maybe we need to develop a **stop** where workers only go down if the loading of new data has stopped and there are no more pending notifications for them to work through.

bq. workers only go down if the loading of new data has stopped and there are no more pending notifications

This sounds very useful.  Could also offer a way to stop workers that waits for currently running transactions to finish, but does not process pending notification.  So there would be three different ways to stop workers : now, after in progress transactions, or after all notifications are processed.
Can this be closed?

> Let yarn handle distribution of jars across cluster. 

I'm so used to pscp'ing my Accumulo iterators already but I see it would be much easier just to supply the jars in one place and have yarn copy them. Especially since this would already have to be done for Accumulo to begin with.

> So there would be three different ways to stop workers : now, after in progress transactions, or after all notifications are processed.

This would certainly help. I'll make a different ticket for this.
The docs suggest using phrasecount if you do not have an app.  Would the trie stress test be another thing to suggest?  I think its docs may need some improvement (for a completely new user).
I like recommending the stress test but the docs need some clean up.  Created a ticket for this. #261

+1

I like the new install docs.   These changes are way too user friendly.
see fluo-io/fluo-io.github.io#34
